job_title: Sr Program Manager in Bellevue, WA
pros:
Amazon is a huge company, trying to judge it as an employer and/or base your opinion based on reviews from people in an organization outside the one you are targeting will be a disservice to yourself. This list is particular to my experience in Alexa International. 

-Leadership: All the leaders I've come across are very supportive of their organization several levels down. They tough but focus on the goals and how to remove obstacles, not where to assign blame. I love my boss.
-Diversity: There is a significant number of women and other minorities in positions of leadership . Even diversity within smaller teams is evident and is a priority. Diversity here goes beyond lip service compared to other companies I've work for that claim they care about diversity.
-Compensation: This is a big tech company, their compensation is high. You can compare it to many other tech companies and chase the dollar signs or better benefits, but at the end of the day you are getting a fair compensation. 
-Quality of people around you: It is very competitive to get in, once you are hired it is a given that you are smart and so are the others around you. Everyone raises the bar together but this is not only from a work competence perspective. People in this organization have a very warm human quality to them that helps the job feel less stressful, helps prioritize your personal life and encourages to grow in ways beyond your assigned work responsibilities.
-Guiding north stars: Every team has very clear goals, scope, guiding north stars and tenets that makes it "easy" even for someone new to feel empowered to make the right decisions even when there are disagreements or the "boss" is not in the room.
-Relocation package: If you are required or want to relocate to your assign city office when taking the job, Amazon offers a great options to match your needs regardless if you are a single person renting or a big family looking to buy a house.
cons:
-Size and communication: While a big company comes with many resources, it also comes with many different teams. This often causes a lot of friction when it comes to sharing details or identifying and involving all affected stakeholders on a timely manner. There are processes in place to minimize this but is a constant struggle, although I wouldn't say it is worse than other companies. 

-Benefits: Compared to other big tech companies, Amazon does not offer the best benefits but they are still good. This comes from their "frugality" mindset.

job_title: Applied Scientist II in Arlington, VA
pros:
I joined fresh after Ph.D. a few months ago and I've heard all kinds of rumors before joining. Here are the pros so far:
- I have learned a lot of new things that actually matter
- I am finally having life, working 9-5 M-F and not even thinking about the work after I close the laptop.
- We get access to paid coursera content for free where we can take any courses we want. I took some personal development and finance courses (it is not relevant to my role in any way).
- I get to go to a few conferences a year, fully paid by my team.
- We don't have to get involved with development if we don't want to. I have AS II teammates who never even bothered to learn how development and putting code into production even works.
- We get to solve very real problems that can have very real immediate impact. You can see in reality how much your work is improving the system or how much it can lower the costs of operations etc.
- Office policy is so flexible that some people have never ever seen their desks.
- Dog friendly offices! Bring your dog every day!
cons:
Of course there are some issues as well:
- No food other than bananas in select offices and coffees/teas.
- Onboarding training includes way too many content and takes a lot of time.
- It feels a bit hard working across the teams to solve an issue owned by another team that affects the results. Even if the solution is simple, it can be really challenging to convince the other team to allow you to fix it.
- The writing culture here can be considered good by some, but is extremely annoying. I have written maybe 20 conference/journal papers before, but it feels like we have to write down in a document everything, way too much, spending most of our time writing rather than doing.
- Publishing is very encouraged, but I've heard getting the actual permission to publish is a bit tricky.
- Vesting schedule is really bad. Along with very average benefits and zero 401 contribution from Amazon unless if you stay for over 3 years.
- Collaboration can be hard when nobody ever comes to the office. Which also in big portion goes back to the food policy.

job_title: Site Safety Manager in Detroit, MI
pros:
Amazon's 14 leadership principles mean that things happen more quickly than in big companies, and bias for action helps get things done. 

This is a casual environment where they don't care how people dress, and they welcome people from all walks of life. 

Amazon genuinely promotes from within and they take great pride in seeing people rise through the ranks.

The pay and benefits are exceptionally good. The Crossover Neighborhood Health Centers in metro areas treat Amazon workers and their families. They offer convenient hours, inexpensive deductibles, and no waiting.

There were many positive employee events. The warehouses are climate-controlled, so associates work in air conditioned / heated environments during weather extremes.
cons:
The company uses emergency medical technicians (EMTs) as onsite medical representatives (OMRs). The job of the OMR is to keep people from seeing a doctor, and Amazon does everything it does to keep injuries in house (medical offices are called Amcare). Because EMTs are not doctors, genuine injuries are sometimes overlooked. 

In July 2022, the Southern District of New York launched an investigation of the Amcare practices. They are investigating nationwide: https://www.justice.gov/usao-sdny/webform/sdny-amazon-warehouse-investigation

Amazon's OSHA recordkeeping was affected by a software change in late 2021. Their injury rate appeared to drop dramatically. In reality, the injuries were not being recorded properly. 

Amazon counts recordable injuries against its management team on the date made recordable, so managers are punished for correcting prior year records.

The general manager where I worked would override any ruling by any of the managers on his team, thereby circumventing any attempts at progressive discipline. An employee who didn't want to work would simply complain to the GM about the manager and the GM would block the manager from holding the person accountable. If that person couldn't get to the GM, the person had the option of taking UPT (unpaid time, available to hourly associates). People who didn't want to show up for work would simply burn their UPT as soon as it dropped into their accounts.

pros: Work from home, career growth, the culture, the compensation. My first few months here has been nothing but smooth and the sky is the limit here when it comes to career growth. They really take care of their employees.
cons: Wish my team had more on site visits with each other. Other than that I have no cons of working here!

review_title: Great team, I've grown professionally, you get what you give
pros:
There are GREAT teams at Amazon, I sit on one of them. This team is collaborative, our director is the best manager I've ever had (in my nearly-20 year career spanning 8 employers) and there are others like them on adjacent teams. 

You get what you put into it -- you can take on stretch projects that positively impact your visibility and impact within the company. 

Working with some of the smartest people I've ever met. Sure, we can disagree (thank goodness, as groupthink kills collaboration), but it's done respectfully.

My role a few years ago is vastly different than what I do now, and I love that I can continue to develop in my role (and I haven't even switched teams).
cons:
Like many companies, work / life harmony is in your hands. You need to set boundaries, or you'll find yourself working a lot, as there's always more to do. 

As has been shared, would be nice to make more... I know people in similar roles to me at Facebook, Google, Apple, and Salesforce with considerably more pay and/or perks. I stay because I love my team and find the work interesting and challenging, but if that were to change, I'd probably chase the $$$.

-you start off with 0 leave and must accrue (many/most offices in my area give you two weeks from start)
